nodes.text: Settler mortality shaped European colonization strategies which determined early institutions that persisted and causally affected current income per capita

Europeans adopted different colonization policies: settler colonies that replicated European institutions (strong property rights, checks on government) versus extractive states designed to transfer resources to the metropole

Historical evidence and examples (e.g., USA, Canada, Australia, New Zealand as Neo-Europes; Congo, many African and some Asian colonies as extractive) show institutional differences aligned with settler presence
Method: Use potential settler mortality (log mortality of soldiers, bishops, sailors from 17th–19th centuries) as an instrument for current institutions to identify causal effect on income

Data sources and construction: mortality measures primarily from Philip D. Curtin (military/naval records), bishops' mortality for Latin America, and other historical sources; institutions proxied by Political Risk Services' protection against expropriation index and Polity constraints variables
First-stage result: log settler mortality strongly negatively predicts current institutions, explaining roughly 25–30 percent of cross-country variation in the institutions index
Reduced-form evidence: countries with higher historical settler mortality are substantially poorer today; strong negative correlation between settler mortality and log GDP per capita (Figure 1)

IV (2SLS) result: instrumenting institutions with settler mortality yields a large, statistically significant effect of institutions on log GDP per capita (baseline coef. ~0.94); quantitatively implies large long-run gains from better institutions (example: improving Nigeria to Chile institutions could imply large multiple increase in income)

Robustness: IV estimates remain similar when excluding Neo-Europes or Africa and after controlling for latitude, colonial identity, legal origin, religion, current disease measures (malaria, life expectancy, infant mortality), natural resources, soil quality, ethnolinguistic fragmentation, and percent European descent

Key identifying assumption: settler mortality affects present-day GDP only through its effect on institutional development (exclusion restriction); argued plausible because malaria and yellow fever were fatal to nonimmune Europeans but had limited direct long-run effects on indigenous adult populations

Overidentification and direct-effect tests: using additional instruments (settlements, early institution measures) and adding log mortality as a regressor find no evidence of a direct effect of settler mortality on current income, supporting the exclusion restriction
Claim: Early institutions created under colonial regimes persisted after independence and formed the basis for current institutions

Evidence for persistence chain: settler mortality -> lower settlement rates; lower settlement -> weaker early institutions (circa 1900 and at independence); early institutions strongly correlated with institutions today (statistical regressions support each link)
OLS findings and endogeneity: OLS shows strong correlation between institutions and income (high R2), but endogeneity and measurement error motivate IV approach

Limitation: measurement error in institutional proxies and impossibility of controlling for all omitted variables; some specifications may underestimate institution effects when controlling for endogenous geographic/health variables treated as exogenous

Conclusion: Empirical evidence indicates institutions are a major determinant of cross-country income differences; once institutions are accounted for, geographic indicators (e.g., distance from the equator or Africa dummy) lose independent explanatory power
